journal-title-group.journal-title: American journal of medical genetics. Part A

title-group.article-title: Cognitive and Behavioral Phenotype of Children with Pseudohypoparathyroidism Type 1A

article-meta.aff: 2Department of Pediatrics, Vanderbilt University Medical Center
3Division of Pediatric Endocrinology, Vanderbilt University Medical Center
4Division of Medical Genetics and Genomic Medicine, Department of Pediatrics, Vanderbilt University Medical Center
5Endocrine Unit and Pediatric Nephrology Unit, Massachusetts General Hospital and Harvard Medical School Boston, MA 02114

author-notes.corresp: Corresponding author: Ashley Shoemaker, MD, MSCI, 1500 21st Ave South St, Suite 1514, Nashville, TN, 37212 USA. Phone: 615-343-8116, Ashley.H.Shoemaker@Vanderbit.Edu

sec.title: Context
sec.p: Pseudohypoparathyroidism 1A (PHP1A) is a rare, genetic disorder. Most patients with PHP1A have cognitive impairment but this has not been systematically studied.

sec.title: Objective
sec.p: To evaluate cognition and behavior in children with PHP1A.

sec.title: Design
sec.p: We prospectively enrolled children with PHP1A, one unaffected sibling (when available) and controls matched on BMI/age/gender/race. Evaluations included cognitive and executive function testing. Parents completed questionnaires on behavior and executive function.

sec.title: Main Outcome Measure
sec.p: We hypothesized that children with PHP1A would have lower intelligent quotient (IQ) scores than controls.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: We enrolled 16 patients with PHP1A, 8 unaffected siblings and 15 controls. Results are presented as mean (SD). The PHP1A group had a composite IQ of 85.9 (17.2); 25% had a composite IQ <-2SD. The PHP1A group had significantly lower IQs than matched controls (composite IQ -17.3, 95%CI -28.1 to -6.5, p< 0.01) and unaffected siblings (composite IQ -21.5, 95%CI -33.9 to -9.1, p< 0.01). Special education services were utilized for 93% of the patients with PHP1A. Deficits were observed in executive function and parents reported delayed adaptive behavior skills and increased rates of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Children with PHP1A have lower intelligence quotient scores, poorer executive function, delayed adaptive behavior skills and increased behavior problems. The majority required special education services.
